text: Most species, such as Nitrospira species (see Tables 18.1 and 18.4), are true lithotrophs or autotrophs, fixing carbon in the form of carbon dioxide or carbonate using carboxysomes.
Chlorobium species require extensive membrane systems full of photopigments for light absorption.

Leptospirillum species are also strict autotrophs, fixing carbon by using Fe2+ Their metabolism generates acid, contributing to acid mine drainage in iron mines at Iron Mountain, California, where they grow in massive pink biofilms.
Their cell structure resembles that of the Proteobacteria, although their phylogenetic branch is deep enough for assignment to a separate phylum.
Their removal of excess nitrite makes a key contribution to aquatic ecosystems.

The chlorophyll reaction centers of Chlorobium are contained within chlorosomes associated with the cytoplasmic membrane (460 nm) and near-infrared (750 nm), thus reflecting the middle range, brownish green.
Another important genus is Leptospirillum, which includes acidophilic iron oxidizers.
Nitrospira species are generally found in freshwater or salt water.
